title: Kenya: Dialogue Still Possible Over Teachers' Salaries
text:
South Africa: Silicosis - Court Lets NGOs Join Class Action 
But the Teachers Service Commission, the Salaries and Remuneration Commission and the National Treasury have ruled out paying the salaries, arguing that the 50-60 per cent salary increase was unaffordable and unsustainable. 
The TSC is even contemplating going to the Supreme Court to appeal the ruling even after it lost the suit a couple of days ago. 
Three critical issues come to the fore. The first is the repercussions of a teachers' strike in the third term when candidates are preparing for national exams. 
Candidates and their parents are agonising over that spectre because of the disruptions in preparations for, and even postponement of, the exams should the strike take off and drag on. 
Second is the implication of paying the Sh17 billion at a time when the government is facing a financial crunch, and the signal it will send to other public workers, who also say they are underpaid. 
The third is the consequence of defying a court ruling by State agencies and hence the government's commitment to the rule of law. 
All the scenarios present difficult choices with no easy solutions. Even so, we still believe that a long-lasting and more accommodating solution can be found through honest and structured dialogue. Kenya
